title: 109_s3758
content: The Secretary of Commerce is restricted from discontinuing or changing the Survey of Income and Program Participation without approval. Proposed actions must be approved in accordance with section 2. The Secretary of Commerce must prepare a written proposal with specific actions, implementation dates, and justifications before discontinuing or changing the Survey of Income and Program Participation. The proposal must be submitted to the SIPP Commission for consideration and decision. The SIPP Commission will promptly review proposals submitted by the Secretary of Commerce regarding changes to the Survey of Income and Program Participation. After deliberation, the Commission will transmit its decision to approve or disapprove the proposal to the Secretary of Commerce in writing, along with reasons and justification. The SIPP Commission will review proposals from the Secretary of Commerce on changes to the Survey of Income and Program Participation and transmit its decision in writing. The SIPP Commission, established to review proposals on changes to the Survey of Income and Program Participation, is composed of members from various government departments. The SIPP Commission consists of members appointed from different government departments, including the Social Security Administration, the Bureau of the Census, and the National Academy of Sciences. Appointments are made based on experience in analyzing household data on economic well-being and government program participation. The SIPP Commission members are appointed for a 2-year term, with vacancies filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget serves as Chairman. The Commission's function is to analyze household data on economic well-being and government program participation. The Commission's function is to consider proposals related to the Survey of Income and Program Participation. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget's functions under this Act are nondelegable. The Commission meets at the Chairman's call, with a majority of eligible members constituting a quorum. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. Members of the Commission receive travel expenses, similar to those serving intermittently in Government, as allowed by section 5703 of title 5, United States Code. The Act will be effective as of the date of enactment or September 30, 2006, whichever comes first.
